title: What Does Musculoskeletal Pain Feel Like? Disorder Medication
author: Medical Author Karthik Kumar; MBBS Medical Reviewer Zilpah Sheikh; MD
description: Musculoskeletal pain causes mild to severe pain in the neck, back, shoulders, hips, legs, or hands. Learn the signs and symptoms, causes, risk factors, diagnosis, and treatment of musculoskeletal pain.
cleaned_text: - [Signs & Symptoms](#what_are_the_common_signs_and_symptoms_of_musculoskeletal_pain) - [Causes & Risk [pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/pain_management/article.htm) affects the muscles, bones, and other structures in the body that support its movement. It can feel like a dull ache, a burning sensation, or a sharp, stabbing [pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/pain_quiz/quiz.htm). The pain could be constant or intermittent and mild to severe. It could be accompanied by [stiffness](https://www.medicinenet.com/joint_stiffness/symptoms.htm), swelling, or [weakness](https://www.medicinenet.com/weakness/symptoms.htm) in the affected area. The following are most commonly susceptible to musculoskeletal pain: - Neck - Back - Shoulders - Hips - Legs - Hands, wrists, elbows, and [feet](https://www.medicinenet.com/feet_facts_quiz/quiz.htm) These areas are particularly susceptible to pain because they are used for a wide range of activities and movements and are often subject to strain and overuse. Additionally, many people experience pain due to underlying health conditions, such as [arthritis](https://www.medicinenet.com/arthritis/article.htm) or [carpal tunnel syndrome](https://www.medicinenet.com/carpal_tunnel_syndrome/article.htm). What are the common signs and symptoms of musculoskeletal pain? Musculoskeletal pain can cause several signs and symptoms. They may vary among people. Usually, people describe the pain as a body ache or pain in pulled or overworked muscles. Common signs and symptoms of musculoskeletal pain - Aching or stiffness in the affected area - Swelling or tenderness in the affected area - Limited range of motion in the affected joint or area - Difficulty moving the affected body part - Muscle weakness or spasms - Redness or warmth to the touch in the affected area - Tingling or numbness in the affected area - Pain that worsens with movement or activity - Pain that is relieved by rest [Fatigue](https://www.medicinenet.com/fatigue/article.htm)or general malaise - Difficulty sleeping due to pain - Unable to lead an independent life In older people, pain could be chronic, lasting for several weeks. What are the common causes of and risk factors for musculoskeletal pain? Common causes of musculoskeletal pain - Overuse or repetitive strain injuries, such as [tennis elbow](https://www.medicinenet.com/tennis_elbow_lateral_epicondylitis/article.htm)or [carpal tunnel bone](https://www.medicinenet.com/broken_bone_types_of_bone_fractures/article.htm) - Degenerative conditions, such as [osteoarthritis](https://www.medicinenet.com/osteoarthritis/article.htm)or stenosis - Inflammatory conditions, such as [rheumatoid arthritis](https://www.medicinenet.com/rheumatoid_arthritis/article.htm)or - Infections, such as [osteomyelitis](https://www.medicinenet.com/osteomyelitis/article.htm)or [septic disorders, such as Paget's disease or [osteoporosis](https://www.medicinenet.com/osteoporosis/article.htm) - Neoplasms or tumors, which affect the musculoskeletal system - A symptom of [fibromyalgia](https://www.medicinenet.com/fibromyalgia_facts/article.htm)or [chronic fatigue syndrome](https://www.medicinenet.com/chronic_fatigue_syndrome/article.htm)or other medical conditions Risk factors for musculoskeletal pain Musculoskeletal pain can affect people of all ages, regardless of their activity levels. Certain groups of people could be at a higher risk of developing this type of pain, including: - Older adults: Muscles and bones may weaken due to age, increasing the risk of injury and pain. - Athletes and physically active people: Engaging in regular physical activity can put extra strain on the muscles and bones, which can lead to pain and injuries. - People with certain medical conditions: Some medical conditions, such as [arthritis](https://www.medicinenet.com/arthritis_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm)and [fibromyalgia](https://www.medicinenet.com/fibromyalgia_pictures_slideshow/article.htm), can cause chronic musculoskeletal pain. - People with sedentary lifestyles: Lack of physical activity can lead to weak muscles and bones, increasing the risk of musculoskeletal pain. - People who perform repetitive tasks: Repeating the same movements repeatedly, such as typing on a keyboard or using tools, can lead to pain in the muscles and joints. - Genetics: Some people could be more likely to experience musculoskeletal pain due to their underlying genetic factors. - Previous injuries: If a person has previously injured a muscle, bone, or joint, they could be more likely to experience pain in that area. - Poor posture: Poor posture can strain the muscles, bones, and joints and lead to pain. [Obesity](https://www.medicinenet.com/obesity_weight_loss/article.htm): Being [overweight](https://www.medicinenet.com/obesity_weight_loss/article.htm)or [obese](https://www.medicinenet.com/obesity_weight_loss/article.htm)can strain muscles, bones, and joints and increase the risk of musculoskeletal pain. If you are experiencing musculoskeletal pain, see a doctor for a proper diagnosis to rule out underlying complications. [](https://www.medicinenet.com/pain_surprising_reasons_pictures_slideshow/article.htm) SLIDESHOWSee Slideshow Can COVID-19 or the monkeypox virus cause musculoskeletal pain? There is limited information on [COVID-19](https://www.medicinenet.com/wuhan_coronavirus_2019-ncov/article.htm) or the [monkeypox](https://www.medicinenet.com/monkeypox/article.htm) virus causing musculoskeletal pain. It is unclear how commonly people have [muscle pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/muscle_pain_myalgia/symptoms.htm) and aches with [COVID-19](https://www.medicinenet.com/wuhan_coronavirus_outbreak_2019-ncov/article.htm) and [monkeypox](https://www.medicinenet.com/monkeypox_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm). Muscle pain could be the result of other factors, such as the body's immune response to the infection. These infections could cause musculoskeletal pain as part of its overall symptoms. If you are experiencing musculoskeletal pain and have been exposed to these [viruses](https://www.medicinenet.com/viral_infections_pictures_slideshow/article.htm), talk to a doctor for diagnosis and treatment. How does a doctor diagnose the cause of musculoskeletal pain? A doctor may diagnose the cause of musculoskeletal pain using the following: - Physical examination: To check for tenderness, swelling, and range of motion in the affected area. They may ask the person to perform certain movements to help diagnose the source of the pain. - Medical history: Any previous injuries or conditions that could be contributing to the pain. - Imaging tests: [X-rays](https://www.medicinenet.com/x-rays/article.htm), [CT scans](https://www.medicinenet.com/cat_scan/article.htm), or [MRI](https://www.medicinenet.com/mri_scan/article.htm)scans to get a better view of the bones, joints, and soft tissues in the affected area. - Laboratory tests: Blood or other laboratory tests to identify underlying conditions that may be causing the pain. In some cases, the doctor may refer the person to a specialist, such as a [rheumatologist](https://www.medicinenet.com/rheumatology/article.htm) or an orthopedist, for further evaluation and treatment. What are the treatment options for musculoskeletal pain? The most appropriate treatment for musculoskeletal pain will depend on the specific cause and location of the pain. Treatment options for musculoskeletal pain include the following: - Rest and physical therapy: - Resting the affected area and using physical therapy can help reduce pain, improve mobility, and allow muscles and joints to heal. - Applying ice or heat to the affected area helps reduce swelling and pain. - Practicing gentle stretching and strengthening exercises to maintain flexibility and support the affected muscles and joints. - Using assistive devices, such as canes or [braces](https://www.medicinenet.com/dental_braces/article.htm), to support the affected area and reduce strain on the muscles and joints. [Over-the-counter](https://www.medicinenet.com/over-the-counter_products/article.htm)pain medication: [Ibuprofen](https://www.medicinenet.com/ibuprofen/article.htm)or [naproxen](https://www.medicinenet.com/naproxen/article.htm)can help relieve pain and inflammation. - Prescription pain medication: Stronger pain medications, such as opioids, could be prescribed by a doctor if over-the-counter options are ineffective. [Corticosteroid](https://www.medicinenet.com/corticosteroids-oral/article.htm)injections: Help reduce inflammation and pain in the affected area. - Surgery: - In severe cases, surgery to repair or remove damaged tissue (such as torn ligaments or cartilage) or correct underlying structural problems. - Physical or occupational therapy may help improve flexibility, strength, and range of motion in the affected area post-surgery. How can I prevent musculoskeletal pain? To prevent musculoskeletal pain, you must maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid activities that put excessive strain on your muscles and joints. Here are some tips to help prevent musculoskeletal pain: - Stay active and engage in regular physical activity, such as [walking](https://www.medicinenet.com/walking/article.htm), [swimming](https://www.medicinenet.com/swimming/article.htm), or [cycling](https://www.medicinenet.com/cycling_biking_or_bicycling/article.htm), to keep your muscles and joints strong and flexible. - Maintain a healthy weight to reduce the amount of strain on your muscles and joints. - Use good posture and body mechanics when lifting, carrying, or performing other activities, and avoid putting unnecessary strain on your muscles and joints. - Take regular breaks when performing activities that require repetitive movements, such as typing or using a computer mouse and keyboard. - Avoid activities that involve high-impact movements or sudden, jarring movements, such as [running](https://www.medicinenet.com/running/article.htm)on hard surfaces or playing contact sports, to reduce your risk of musculoskeletal injuries. Musculoskeletal pain can last for varying times depending on the underlying cause of pain and its treatment approach. If you have a chronic musculoskeletal condition, such as arthritis, talk to your doctor about ways to manage your condition and prevent pain. They may recommend medication, physical therapy, or other treatments to help you manage your pain. What is idiopathic musculoskeletal pain? Idiopathic musculoskeletal pain is [chronic pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/chronic_pain_causes_solutions_pictures_slideshow/article.htm) and system. Unlike other forms of [chronic pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/chronic_pain/symptoms.htm), idiopathic musculoskeletal pain does not have a known cause and can be difficult to diagnose and treat. Some of the most common types of idiopathic musculoskeletal pain include: [Fibromyalgia](https://www.medicinenet.com/fibromyalgia_quiz/quiz.htm), which affects the muscles and soft tissues - Chronic [low back pain](https://www.medicinenet.com/low_back_pain/article.htm) - Other conditions that can cause idiopathic pain include [osteoarthritis](https://www.medicinenet.com/osteoarthritis_oa_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm), Treatment for idiopathic musculoskeletal pain can be challenging because the exact cause of the pain is often unknown. - Doctors may recommend physical therapy or [exercise](https://www.medicinenet.com/exercise/article.htm)to help strengthen the affected muscles and improve the range of motion. - Pain medication and anti-inflammatory [drugs](https://www.medicinenet.com/drugs_what_you_should_know_about_your_drugs/article.htm)could be prescribed to help relieve symptoms. - In some cases, alternative treatments, such as [acupuncture](https://www.medicinenet.com/acupuncture/article.htm), massage therapy, or chiropractic care, may help manage idiopathic musculoskeletal pain. Living with idiopathic musculoskeletal pain can be difficult. You can take steps to manage your symptoms and improve your quality of life. - Staying active and exercising regularly can help maintain strength and flexibility and improve mood and overall well-being - Eating a healthy [diet](https://www.medicinenet.com/diet_plans_and_programs/article.htm) - Getting enough [sleep](https://www.medicinenet.com/sleep/article.htm)can help manage pain and promote overall health - Avoiding activities that cause pain or discomfort - Finding ways to relax and manage [stress](https://www.medicinenet.com/stress/article.htm)can help manage idiopathic musculoskeletal pain If you are living with idiopathic musculoskeletal pain, work with your specialist to develop a treatment plan that is right for you. With the right treatment and support, you can manage your pain and live a fulfilling life. Which vitamin supplementation may help with musculoskeletal pain? [Vitamin D deficiency](https://www.medicinenet.com/vitamin_d_deficiency/article.htm) has been linked to musculoskeletal pain. Taking a [vitamin D](https://www.medicinenet.com/vitamin_d-oral/article.htm) supplement could be helpful. [Vitamin D](https://www.medicinenet.com/nutritional_health_vitamin_d_pictures_slideshow/article.htm) helps maintain healthy bones by supporting the body to absorb calcium. You may take a calcium supplement as well because adequate calcium intake is essential for healthy bones. Talk to your doctor before starting any new supplement regimen to ensure it is safe for you and will not interact with any medications you take. Limited studies suggest that vitamin supplementation can specifically help with musculoskeletal pain. The severity of ankle sprains ranges from mild (which can resolve within 24 hours) to severe (which can require surgical repair). Tendinitis of the ankle can be caused by trauma or inflammation. Can Back Pain Cause Your Stomach to Swell?Back pain and bloating often go hand in hand and can be caused by a wide range of conditions, from herniated discs to pregnancy. Learn about common causes of back pain and stomach swelling, and check out the center below for more medical references on pain management, including multimedia (slideshows, images, and quizzes), related diseases, treatment, diagnosis, medications, and prevention or wellness. Foot Pain SlideshowLearn about common causes of foot pain such as bunions, corns, athlete's foot, plantar warts and more. Get the latest information on treatments for foot pain. Knee PainAcute injuries, medical conditions, and chronic use conditions are causes of knee pain. Symptoms and signs that accompany knee pain include redness, swelling, difficulty walking, and locking of the knee. To diagnose knee pain, a physician will perform a physical exam and also may order X-rays, arthrocentesis, blood tests, or a CT scan or MRI. Treatment of knee pain depends upon the cause of the pain. Lower Back Pain (Lumbar Spine Pain)There are many causes of back pain. Pain in the low back can relate to the bony lumbar spine, discs between the vertebrae, ligaments around the spine and discs, spinal cord and nerves, muscles of the low back, internal organs of the pelvis, and abdomen, and the skin covering the lumbar area. Neck Pain (Cervical Pain)Neck pain (cervical pain, cervicalgia) may be caused by any number of disorders and diseases. Tenderness is another symptom of neck pain. Though treatment for neck pain really depends upon the cause, treatment typically may involve heat/ice application, traction, physical therapy, cortisone injection, topical anesthetic creams, and muscle relaxants. Neck Pain and DizzinessNeck pain and dizziness are both symptoms that may result from several causes and risk factors. Check out the center below for more medical references on neck pain and dizziness, including multimedia (slideshows, images, and quizzes), related disease conditions, treatment and diagnosis, medications, and prevention or wellness. Pain ManagementPain management and treatment can be simple or complex, according to its cause. There are two basic types of pain, nociceptive pain and neuropathic pain. Some causes of neuropathic pain include: - complex regional pain syndrome, - interstitial cystitis, - and irritable bowel syndrome. Pain Management: Why Does My Calf Muscle Hurt?There's a group of muscles on the back of each lower leg that doctors call "calf muscles." They play a key role in helping you walk and run. Learn the things that can make them hurt, from a minor sprain to more serious problems like deep vein thrombosis. Pain Management: Why Knees HurtYour knees have lots of parts, and you use them a lot, so there's plenty that could go wrong. WebMD explains common things that can cause knee pain. Pelvic Pain (in Women and Men) Pelvic pain is described as pain, usually in the lower pelvic area. Causes of acute and chronic pelvic pain in women include endometriosis, ectopic pregnancy, miscarriage, menstrual cramps, ovarian cysts, tumors, or fibroids, ovulation, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) or congestion syndrome, vulva pain, and rarely cancer. Pelvic pain during pregnancy may be caused by miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy (tubal pregnancy), preterm or premature labor, and placental abruption. Causes of pelvic pain in men include prostate problems, testicular pain, and groin pain. Causes of pelvic pain in men and women include kidney stones, appendicitis, UTIs, IBD, and STDs. Signs and symptoms associated with pelvic pain depend on the cause, but man include pain during or after sexual intercourse, abdominal pain, distension, and tenderness, diarrhea, constipation, vaginal discharge or bleeding, blood, pus, in the urine, cloudy urine, blood in the stool, stool color changes, and low back pain. The cause of pelvic pain is diagnosed by a physical exam, blood tests, and imaging procedures. Treatment for pelvic pain depends on the cause. What Helps Knee Pain from Sitting All Day?Knee pain can affect people at any age and can result from an injury or some type of medical condition. Things that help knee pain from sitting all day include the right mixture of stretching and strengthening exercises to help by improving joint movement and functioning. What Is the Strongest Painkiller?The most powerful pain reliever is a class of medications known as "opioids," which have a significant risk of addiction and dependency. These drugs are routinely recommended by doctors for severe pain treatment, as well as a variety of other illnesses.
